description: Enum, IntEnum, StrEnum, auto(), pattern matching with enums, and iteration

cards.front: What is an enum and why use it?
cards.back:
A set of named constants. Replaces magic strings and numbers.

from enum import Enum

class Color(Enum):
    RED = "red"
    GREEN = "green"
    BLUE = "blue"

Benefits: autocomplete, typo protection, clear documentation.
Color.REED raises AttributeError immediately. "reed" would silently fail.

cards.front: What is the difference between Enum, IntEnum, and StrEnum?
cards.back:
Enum: members are NOT equal to their values
  Color.RED == "red"  # False

IntEnum: members behave like integers
  Priority.HIGH == 3  # True
  Priority.HIGH > Priority.LOW  # True

StrEnum (3.11+): members behave like strings
  Status.ACTIVE == "active"  # True
  f"{Status.ACTIVE}"  # "active"

Automatically assigns incrementing integer values starting from 1.

from enum import Enum, auto

class Direction(Enum):
    NORTH = auto()  # 1
    SOUTH = auto()  # 2
    EAST = auto()   # 3
    WEST = auto()   # 4

Useful when the specific value does not matter — only the name.

cards.front: How do you iterate over an enum?
cards.back:
Enums are iterable:

for season in Season:
    print(f"{season.name} = {season.value}")

All values: [s.value for s in Season]
All names: [s.name for s in Season]

.name gives the string name ("SPRING")
.value gives the assigned value (1 or "spring")

cards.front: How do you look up an enum member by name or value?
cards.back:
By name: Color["RED"]     # Color.RED
By value: Color("red")    # Color.RED

Check membership:
"RED" in Color.__members__  # True

Lookup by value raises ValueError if not found:
Color("purple")  # ValueError!

cards.front: Why does Color.RED == "red" return False with regular Enum?
cards.back:
Regular Enum members are NOT equal to their values.

Color.RED == "red"        # False
Color.RED.value == "red"  # True
Color.RED is Color.RED    # True

This is by design — enums are distinct types.
Use StrEnum if you need value comparisons to work naturally.

cards.front: How do enums work with match/case?
cards.back:
Enums pair naturally with pattern matching:

def handle(cmd: Command) -> str:
    match cmd:
        case Command.START:  return "Starting..."
        case Command.STOP:   return "Stopping..."
        case Command.PAUSE:  return "Pausing..."

Use dotted names (Command.START) not bare names in patterns.

cards.front: Can you modify enum members after creation?
cards.back:
No. Enums are immutable.

Color.RED = "crimson"  # AttributeError!

Enum members are singletons:
Color("red") is Color.RED  # True — same object

You cannot create new members or change existing ones at runtime.
